<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 262, 170, 278]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 286, 393, 302]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[747, 262, 861, 278]]<|/det|>
9702/51  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[744, 286, 861, 302]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[722, 310, 861, 325]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 338, 376, 354]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 365, 343, 380]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 397, 212, 412]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 413, 768, 533]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 560, 203, 574]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 575, 693, 606]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 91, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 67, 875, 87]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the current in a coil and a resistor connected in series, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 97, 680, 145]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 163, 507, 180]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 191, 875, 209]]<|/det|>
The student connects a high-voltage d.c. power supply and a switch across the series combination.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 221, 875, 253]]<|/det|>
When the switch is closed, it takes time \(t\) for the current in the resistor of resistance \(R\) to reach a maximum value. The time \(t\) is a few milliseconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 265, 593, 282]]<|/det|>
There are a number of different unmarked resistors available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 294, 541, 312]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(t\) and \(R\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 316, 512, 348]]<|/det|>
\[t = \frac{KN^2A}{LR}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 354, 875, 387]]<|/det|>
where \(N\) is the number of turns of wire on the coil, \(A\) is the cross-sectional area of the coil, \(L\) is the length of the coil and \(K\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 399, 675, 416]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(t\) and \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 413, 635, 430]]<|/det|>
Explain how your results could be used to determine a value for \(K\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 441, 875, 473]]<|/det|>
You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account you should pay particular attention to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 486, 376, 504]]<|/det|>
● the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 515, 390, 532]]<|/det|>
● the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 543, 331, 560]]<|/det|>
● the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 571, 334, 588]]<|/det|>
● the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 599, 425, 615]]<|/det|>
● any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 91, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 67, 875, 101]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the collision of two gliders A and B on a linear air-track. A card is attached to glider B, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 112, 767, 237]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 250, 507, 267]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 279, 541, 297]]<|/det|>
Glider B has a mass \(M.\) A mass \(m\) is added to glider B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 308, 875, 341]]<|/det|>
Glider A travels at a constant velocity \(u\) towards the stationary glider B. The gliders then collide and move together towards the light gate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 352, 875, 384]]<|/det|>
The card passes through the light gate which is connected to a data logger. The student records the velocity \(v\) of the two gliders from the data logger.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 396, 601, 414]]<|/det|>
The student changes the mass \(m\) and repeats the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 425, 546, 443]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(v\) and \(m\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 455, 551, 473]]<|/det|>
\[Au = (M + m + A)v\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 485, 363, 503]]<|/det|>
where \(A\) is the mass of glider A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 512, 139, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 508, 670, 534]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\frac{1}{v}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \((M + m)\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 543, 583, 561]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 691, 875, 709]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 720, 875, 738]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 736, 876, 754]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 139, 85]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 67, 468, 85]]<|/det|> Values of \(m\) and \(v\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 97, 383, 114]]<|/det|> The value of \(M\) is \(330 \text{g} \pm 5\%\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 111, 581, 129]]<|/det|> Each value of \(m\) has a percentage uncertainty of \(\pm 5\%\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 141, 514, 158]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 170, 791, 457]]<|/det|>
\(m/\mathrm {g}\)\((M+m)/g\)\(\nu /\mathrm {cm}\mathrm {s}^{-1}\)\(\frac {1}{\nu }/\mathrm {s}\mathrm {cm}^{-1}\)
504.42
1503.92
2503.40
3503.02
5002.58
6002.33
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 460, 687, 490]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \((M + m) / \mathrm{g}\) and \(\frac{1}{\nu} /\mathrm{scm}^{-1}\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 485, 504, 504]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \((M + m)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 485, 876, 504]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 515, 136, 533]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 511, 175, 532]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 510, 532, 534]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{\nu} /\mathrm{scm}^{-1}\) against \((M + m) / \mathrm{g}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 543, 425, 562]]<|/det|> Include error bars for \((M + m)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 543, 876, 562]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 574, 171, 592]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 573, 876, 606]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Both lines should be clearly labelled. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 588, 876, 606]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 617, 170, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 617, 876, 650]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 826, 876, 845]]<|/det|>
gradient = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 68, 175, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 67, 875, 101]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 210, 876, 229]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 241, 141, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 241, 178, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 240, 798, 275]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(u\) and \(A\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 428, 873, 446]]<|/det|>
<form>u = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 457, 875, 476]]<|/det|>
<form>A = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 473, 876, 491]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 502, 175, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 501, 524, 520]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 631, 876, 650]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty in \(A =\) ................................................... % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 661, 141, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 660, 876, 694]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated. Determine the value of \(m\) that would give a velocity \(v\) of \(2.0 \text{cm s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 794, 876, 813]]<|/det|>
<form>m = .................................................... g [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[792, 823, 876, 841]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 15]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 860, 875, 895]]<|/det|>
